column47: VERY intelligent manipulations of audience expectations
column48: and strong cinematography throughout. And most importantly
column49:
it evoked the same feelings for me as the original trilogy.

People who rail on the film are mostly diehard fans who are upset that this film features dynamic characters and adds real alterations to the traditional Star Wars formula...or people who took those fans at their word when they said the movie was bad. I won\'t go into detail for fear of spoilers
column50: but real people change over the course of their lives
column51:
and Luke\'s changes in outlook due to the events between Episode 6 and this episode are not only believable but the reason that he is one of this episode\'s most interesting characters. The dozens of other "plot holes" I\'ve heard brought up are (with the singular exception of Holdo\'s poor communication with Poe) simply failures to read between the lines.

This is a very clever film that also expects a more from its audience than the original trilogy
column52: and the (at the time of this writing) 90% critic score reflects that. '

column70: awful! Actually makes TFA a decent movie! It also has the uncanny ability to actually make the 1977-83 movies less interesting! While I understand what director Rian Johnson was trying to do - his writing style and direction literally killed the film. Every major character arc and loose thread from Force Awakens is either ignored or destroyed entirely. Every beloved character is brushed aside or unceremoniously discarded. What\'s left behind is an often awkwardly-funny
column106: shallow shell of a star wars movie that feels overlong
column107: and often times takes us down unnecessary paths. Little respect was given to star wars lore here and with the mantra "everything old must die" - what its replaced with doesn\'t instill much excitment for the future of the series. JJ Abrams has a lot of work to do if he wants to save this trilogy. '
